docs.abstract: Corixa Corp agrees to buy Coulter Pharmaceutical for stock worth about $900 million; acquisition is one of largest ever between two biotechnology companies (M)

headline.main: In Big Biotech Merger, Corixa Plans to Buy Coulter Pharmaceutical for $900 Million

docs.lead_paragraph: The Corixa Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Coulter Pharmaceutical, gaining access to a potentially promising cancer drug and a sales force. The acquisition, for stock worth about $900 million when the deal was announced, is one of the largest ever between two biotechnology companies. Corixa, based in Seattle, is developing various vaccines and other drugs that aim to harness the body's immune system to fight disease. Coulter, based in South San Francisco, works in the closely related area of monoclonal antibodies, which are engineered versions of proteins the immune system uses to fend off bacteria or viruses.

docs.abstract: SBC Communications Inc targets more than 30 cities in which to begin competing for local telephone service; invades realms of incumbents BellSouth, Verizon and Qwest; photo, drawing (M)

headline.main: SBC Is Going National With Its Local Service

docs.lead_paragraph: East Wareham, Mass., near the Cape Cod canal about an hour south of Boston, is not generally known as one of the telecommunications industry's hotbeds of competition. But do not tell that to Gary D. Powers. Mr. Powers is president of Abbey Glass, a small glass installer and distributor in East Wareham. His company, with nine employees and perhaps a half-dozen phones, is also a pioneer of what could be the most ambitious plan yet to give consumers and businesses across the country a choice in local communications providers.

docs.abstract: Genuity Inc, one of world's first biggest Internet carriers, plans to introduce its first major service offerings since company was spun off from GTE Corp this summer; new suite of services is meant to help Genuity's corporate customers do business on the Internet; Genuity is trying to offer services that are more sophisticated and profitable than providing raw Internet access (M)

headline.main: Genuity to Introduce First Major Internet Service Offerings

docs.lead_paragraph: Genuity Inc., one of the world's biggest Internet carriers, plans today to introduce its first major service offerings since the company was spun off from the GTE Corporation this summer. Unsurprisingly, the new suite of services is meant to help Genuity's corporate customers do business on the Internet. Long one of the biggest carriers of Internet traffic, Genuity, formerly known as BBN, is trying to offer services that are more sophisticated and profitable than providing raw Internet access.

docs.abstract: Go.com, Walt Disney Co's attempt to build Internet portal, is starting up again after nine-month absense; Go will test new design beginning Sept 15; for users, it is much leaner model, focused almost entirely on searching, rather than complex, all-purpose vehicle of Go's previous design; there is will be fewer cross-promotions of other Disney sites (M)

headline.main: Disney Redesigns Go.com In a Push to Attract Surfers

docs.lead_paragraph: Go.com is starting up again after a nine-month pit stop. Go, which was the Walt Disney Company's attempt to build an Internet portal to take on the likes of Yahoo, will test a new design beginning today.

byline.original: By SIMON ROMERO and JULIAN E. BARNES

docs.abstract: Verizon Communications and striking employees reportedly reach agreement on issue at heart of dispute; company reportedly will make it easier for unions to organize some of employees currently in nonunion jobs in wireless division (M)

headline.main: Accord Is Seen On Key Issue In Phone Strike

docs.lead_paragraph: In a development that could hasten the end of the strike by more than 86,000 employees of Verizon Communications, the company and its unions resolved an issue at the heart of their dispute yesterday, people close to the talks said. Verizon will make it easier for the unions to organize some of the employees currently in nonunion jobs in the company's wireless division, those close to the talks said. The unit, Verizon Wireless, is the nation's largest wireless operator, and its employees are not striking. The wireless operation is managed and majority owned by Verizon, the nation's largest telecommunications employer, in a venture with Vodafone AirTouch of Britain.

docs.abstract: National Venture Capital Association reports that $24.billion in venture capital was invested in second quarter of 2000, compared with $24.8 billion in first quarter; says that during quarter electronic-commerce companies fell out of favor with venture capitalists, whose Internet-related investments focused increasingly on communications and infrastructure startups; graph (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Even as the public stock markets cooled, the level of venture capital investment nationwide was little changed in the second quarter, the National Venture Capital Association reported yesterday. In fact, more companies received investments in the April-June period than in either of the previous two quarters, though the amount invested declined slightly for the second consecutive quarter after growing at a blistering pace last year.

docs.abstract: Microsoft Corp is developing software meant to shield people from electronic and voice mail, appointment requests, Internet information and other electronic distractions while they are working; many computer-design experts believe restricting such interruptions to only the most urgent ones has become a pressing necessity in the Internet age; research on software, called Attention User Interface, is led by Eric Horvitz, and his work makes use of statistical techniques developed by Thomas Bayes in 18th century; photo (M)

headline.main: Microsoft Sees Software 'Agent' as Way to Avoid Distractions

docs.lead_paragraph: Attention, please. Hoping to shed its longstanding industry reputation as a mere imitator, not an innovator, Microsoft is spending heavily on research in a wide range of software technologies that include hand-held computing and voice recognition. But the most intriguing project may be taking place in the cramped office of Eric Horvitz, a devotee of an obscure, 17-century statistical technique that plays a key role in his current work.
docs.snippet: Attention, please.     Hoping to shed its longstanding industry reputation as a mere imitator, not an innovator, Microsoft is spending heavily on research in a wide range of software technologies that include hand-held computing and voice recognit...

docs.abstract: Inktomi and Akamai, leaders in Web-performance industry, are taking different approaches to technology of speeding Internet transmissions and to how they should be paid for services; Inktomi, with America Online as trophy client, aims to make Web traffic flow faster by storing or 'caching' most frequently requested data on network server computers nearest to people who request it; Akamai, with Yahoo among big clients, uses content distribution technique, with only first request going to Yahoo's main server and balance of page delivered from Akamai server with best link to user; diagram; graphs and tables of corporate data; photos (M)

headline.main: 2 Companies Take Separate Paths To Speed Delivery of Web Pages

docs.lead_paragraph: Here's news: Some of the Internet's uncertainties have nothing to do with stock prices. Take the vagaries of surfing the Web, for example. Anyone who has ever watched a complex Web page paint itself onto the computer screen, image by grudgingly slow image, can attest that the World Wide Web should be faster. On that simple proposition there is virtually unanimous agreement.

docs.abstract: Bill Joy, chief scientist of Sun Microsystems, issues impassioned critique of uncontrolled progress in digital, biological and material sciences; his essay in April issue of Wired magazine challenges scientists and engineers to rethink their ethical standards and step back from advances that might ultimately threaten human species; Joy writes that world has survived potentially devastating technologies developed in 20th century, but that several new branches of research pose threats of technological devastation at hands of small group or even individual; says some 21st century technologies--genetics, nanotechnology and robotics--are so powerful they can spawn whole new classes of accidents and abuses; calls on scientists to limit development of technologies that are too dangerous; photos (M)

headline.main: Technologists Get a Warning and a Plea From One of Their Own

docs.lead_paragraph: An unlikely prophet is voicing a plea for reason and restraint in the increasingly chaotic stampede toward the technological future. Breaking ranks with the customarily optimistic and self-congratulatory high-technology industry, Bill Joy, the chief scientist of Sun Microsystems, has issued an impassioned critique of uncontrolled progress in digital, biological and material sciences. He has challenged scientists and engineers to rethink their ethical standards and step back from advances that might ultimately threaten the human species.

docs.abstract: 3Com Corp reports fiscal second quarter loss of $142.4 million compared with net income of $177.3 million a year earlier; revenue in period ended Dec 1 dropped 35 percent, to $789 million (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The 3Com Corporation, the maker of computer-networking equipment, reported a fiscal second-quarter loss today that was narrower than the reduced forecast it issued earlier this month. The company lost $142.4 million, or 41 cents a share, in contrast to net income of $177.3 million, or 51 cents, a year earlier. Excluding reorganization and other costs and gains, the loss was $52.4 million, or 15 cents a share. Revenue in the period ended Dec. 1 dropped 35 percent, to $789.5 million, after 3Com predicted sales of $765 million to $780 million.
